name: Lucid
headline: Fast world models for generative simulations
description:
We are building generative simulations of the world powered by fast world models.

Instead of using a physics or game engine with hard-coded rules to render each frame and decide how the environment reacts, this is done end-to-end through a neural network.

Unlike text-to-video models, our world models generate frames conditioned on actions, enabling real-time interaction with any environment. Users can explore, manipulate objects, and shape their experience through natural gameplay.

We trained a model to emulate Minecraft that runs smoothly on consumer hardware (1B param model runs at 25fps on an nvidia 4090 gaming gpu while other Minecraft world models run at <3fps). Our advantage in speed comes from aggressive latent compression (128x) that allows us to encode every frame into only 15 tokens while others traditionally use 256.

We are now training on real-world footage and are building a general-purpose universe simulator.

founders.name: Alberto Hojel, Founder
founders.description:
Studied computer science at UC Berkeley and did research at BAIR under Trevor Darrell. Worked on weather forecasting with ML at Rainmaker. Originally from Mexico City.

Was on track to pursue a PhD but realized I wanted to build something greater while presenting my paper at ECCV.

Passionate about lucid dreaming and immersive content.

founders.name: Rami Seid, Co-Founder
founders.description: A high school dropout who got his first internship as an MLE at a robotics lab, I went on to become the CTO of a govtech contracting company. After that, I cofounded my own telecommunications company while doing ML work on the side. Now I'm building a universe simulator at Lucid.

**Lucid Simulations: Crafting a New Reality**

Lucid Simulations is on a mission that resonates with futurists: creating fast and dynamic generative simulations of our world using cutting-edge technology. Founded in 2024, and a proud member of Y Combinator Batch W25, Lucid is setting its sights on building an interactive environment where users can explore and shape their experiences live.

At the core of Lucid's innovation is a departure from the traditional methods of simulation. Instead of relying on physics or game engines with cumbersome hard-coded rules, Lucid employs a neural network that seamlessly renders the world in real-time. This approach enables users to interact naturally with their surroundings and manipulate their environments as if they were playing a game.

One of Lucid’s standout achievements is their Minecraft emulation model. Unlike typical models that struggle with performance (often rendering at less than 3 frames per second), Lucid’s version runs at an impressive 25 frames per second on standard gaming hardware, such as an NVIDIA 4090 GPU. This is made possible through aggressive latent compression techniques, allowing them to encode each frame into just 15 tokens, compared to the usual 256 used by other models.

As they move forward, Lucid is not stopping at gaming worlds. The team is now diving into real-world footage training, aiming to build a general-purpose universe simulator that faithfully adheres to the physics and dynamics of reality. 

Based in Berkeley, CA, Lucid operates with a tight-knit team of four, including founders Alberto Hojel and Rami Seid. They’re backed by the robust support of Y Combinator, which gives them a solid foundation to grow from. 

If you want to keep a pulse on their developments or wish to join their journey, you can check out their website at [Lucid Simulations](https://lucidsim.co/) or shoot them an email at alberto@lucidsim.co.

In a world growing increasingly complex, Lucid is making strides to simplify the way we interact with simulations, blending imagination with the realities of fast computing. Keep an eye on them; they’re just getting started.
